title: Synthetic Recap
body:
WASHINGTON – In the heart of the nation's capital, Allen Iverson wasn't just a rookie; he was a force of nature. On a night where offense was at a premium, the Philadelphia 76ers' phenom authored a historic individual performance, carrying his team to a grinding 99-93 victory over the Washington Bullets.

From the opening tip, this was the Iverson Show. While others struggled to find a rhythm, the No. 1 overall pick was a blur of crossover dribbles and acrobatic finishes, slicing through the Bullets' defense with breathtaking audacity. He poured in a game-high **40 points**, a staggering total that accounted for over 40 percent of the 76ers' offense. Each basket was a necessity, a counterpunch to a resilient Washington squad that refused to fade.

The Bullets, led by Chris Webber's 20 points and 12 rebounds, and Juwan Howard's 19 and 10, battled tirelessly in the paint. Yet, every time they threatened to seize momentum, Iverson had an answer—a deep three, a relentless drive, a steal leading to a transition bucket. His six assists proved he was a conductor as well as a scorer, creating just enough opportunities for his teammates to supplement his explosive output.

In the final minutes, with the game hanging in the balance, it was Iverson who iced the victory from the charity stripe, a fitting end to a masterclass. This was more than just a win; it was a declaration. On this night, Allen Iverson announced to the league that he was not just the future, but a present-day superstar capable of single-handedly winning games. The final score read 76ers 99, Bullets 93, but the story was singular, written in the indelible ink of one man's 40-point masterpiece.
